page.title: 13Mr.Whittle's Farm
page.content: Mr. Whittle farms 230 acres. Most of this is for corn production, the remainder being used for grazing his pedigree shorthorn cattle. This herd was set up by his father in 1920, but Mr. Whittle stopped milking 5 years ago because of E.E.C. subsidies. His calves now suckle and are sold at Taunton Market. He now uses artificial insemination for breeding. Due to increased labour costs he has also switched from the production of rootcrops to wheat as this is much easier to harvest. He is still short-handed though. Some winter grazing is let to sheep when the cattle are taken in. Winter feed has also become much more expensive and he has changed from hay to sugar beet tops.
